sections.1_story_intuition: Physics is the study of matter, energy, and the laws governing their interactions. Understanding basic principles of physics is essential for competitive exams, as questions often focus on fundamental laws, units, and applications in daily life.
2_key_definitions: Force: A push or pull acting on an object.
Energy: The ability to do work.
Work: Product of force and displacement.
Speed: Distance covered per unit time.
Velocity: Speed in a given direction.
Acceleration: Rate of change of velocity.
Friction: Resistance to motion between two surfaces.
Gravity: Force of attraction between objects.
3_key_facts_data_points: Archimedes' Principle: Upthrust on a body equals the weight of fluid displaced.
Pascal's Law: Pressure applied to a fluid is transmitted equally.
Newton's First Law: Law of inertia.
Newton's Second Law: F = m x a.
Newton's Third Law: Every action has an equal and opposite reaction.
Ohm's Law: V = I x R.
Heat flows from hot to cold.
4_micro_notes: Newton is the SI unit of force.
Joule is the SI unit of energy.
Watt is the SI unit of power.
Speed of light is 3 x 10^8 m/s.
Ohm's Law: V = I x R.
Heat flows from hot to cold.
5_exam_capsules: What is the SI unit of force? Newton.
What is the SI unit of energy? Joule.
What is the SI unit of power? Watt.
What is the speed of light? 3 x 10^8 m/s.
What is the value of gravity? 9.8 m/s¬≤.
What is Ohm's Law? V = I x R.
What is Newton's First Law? Law of inertia.
What is Newton's Second Law? F = m x a.
What is Newton's Third Law? Action and reaction.
What is Archimedes' Principle? Upthrust equals weight of fluid displaced.
What is Pascal's Law? Pressure is transmitted equally in fluids.
What is the formula for density? Mass / Volume.
What is the formula for pressure? Force / Area.
What is the formula for power? Work / Time.
What is the formula for work? Force x Displacement.
What is refraction? Bending of light.
What is reflection? Bouncing back of light.
7_traps_confusing_points: Mixing up SI units of energy and power.
Assuming sound travels fastest in air.
Mixing up formulas for work and power.
Confusing Ohm's Law with Newton's Laws.

8_case_study_context.title: Archimedes' Principle in Daily Life
8_case_study_context.explanation: Archimedes' Principle explains why objects float or sink in water. Ships are designed to displace enough water to balance their weight, ensuring they float. This principle is widely used in shipbuilding and submarine design.
